questions.question: Which of the following is a key difference between supervised and unsupervised learning?

options.A: Supervised learning uses labeled data, while unsupervised learning uses unlabeled data.
options.B: Unsupervised learning is faster than supervised learning.
options.C: Supervised learning is used for clustering tasks.
options.D: Unsupervised learning requires more training data.

questions.question: Which algorithm is specifically designed for handling large datasets with many features?
Which evaluation metric is used to measure the proportion of actual positives correctly identified by a classification model?
What is the primary purpose of feature scaling in machine learning?

options.A: To increase the number of features
options.B: To ensure all features have equal importance
options.C: To normalize the range of feature values
options.D: To reduce the dimensionality of data

questions.question: Which of the following methods is used for dimensionality reduction?
Which clustering algorithm is sensitive to the order of data points and can yield different results with different initializations?
In Bayesian networks, what does a directed acyclic graph (DAG) represent?
Which method is commonly used for feature selection in machine learning to reduce dimensionality and improve model efficiency?
Which type of ensemble learning technique combines the predictions of multiple models through a weighted voting system?
What is the primary purpose of the Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm in unsupervised learning?

options.A: It estimates the parameters of a statistical model when some data is missing.
options.B: It maximizes the likelihood of the observed data by iteratively updating model parameters.
options.C: It computes the posterior probabilities of data points belonging to different clusters.
options.D: It prevents overfitting by regularizing model weights.

questions.question: Which metric is commonly used to evaluate the quality of clusters in hierarchical clustering?
In Hidden Markov Models (HMMs), what does the transition matrix represent?

options.A: The probability of transitioning between hidden states
options.B: The probability of emitting observations from hidden states
options.C: The initial probabilities of each hidden state

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of using a Bayesian neural network over a standard neural network?

options.C: Better handling of uncertainty through probabilistic modeling

questions.question: Which method is commonly used for outlier detection in high-dimensional datasets?
In reinforcement learning, what is the purpose of the 'exploration vs. exploitation' dilemma?

options.A: Balancing the trade-off between discovering new actions and exploiting known actions for maximum reward
options.B: Identifying the best policy for a given environment
options.C: Minimizing the variance in reward estimates

questions.question: Which type of learning is characterized by a model that can adapt and improve its performance over time as it receives more data?
What is the primary goal of the forward pass in a neural network during training?

options.B: Propagating errors backward through the layers
options.C: Making predictions and comparing them to target values

questions.question: In machine learning, what does the term 'bias-variance trade-off' refer to?

options.A: Balancing the bias of a model with the variance of its predictions
options.B: Increasing the bias of a model to reduce overfitting
options.C: Maximizing both bias and variance to improve model accuracy
options.D: Minimizing both bias and variance to achieve the best model performance

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Baum-Welch algorithm in Hidden Markov Models (HMMs)?

options.B: Decoding the most likely state sequence
options.C: Learning the model parameters from observed sequences
options.D: Calculating the posterior probabilities of states

questions.question: Which technique is used to address the vanishing gradient problem in deep neural networks?
